tossups.question: One family from this city, the Embriaco, stylized themselves as the Lords of Gibelet, since they ruled the `	city of Byblos. The Bank of Saint George operated in this city. It's not Rome, but one leader of this city, who took the title of "perpetual censor," reformed its constitution to create the alberghi. The decision to catapult bodies over one colony controlled by this city in Gazaria likely contributed to the Black Death; that city on the (*) Black Sea is Caffa. The Battle of Preveza saw the defeat of one admiral from this city, Andrea Doria. This city controlled the island of Corsica to its south. Like Venice, this city was led by a doge. For 10 points, name this Italian city on the Liguarian sea, the birthplace of Christopher Columbus.

This building is referred to as an "Enigma" in the title of a Joan Breton Connelly book. Alan LeQuire created a gilded replica of a sculpture from this building. The columns of this building lean slightly inward, likely to give the building an appearance of strength, although its stylobate is curved. A frieze in this building shows twelve figures with their backs turned to children helping an adult fold a piece of cloth. (*) Ictinus and Callicrates designed this building. A replica of this building in Nashville contains a recreation of the chryselephantine statue of its dedicatee that was made by Phidias. The Elgin Marbles were taken from this building to the British Museum. For 10 points, name this large temple on the Acropolis dedicated to Athena.

A poem named for a village in this country notes that "The houses are all gone under the sea / The dancers are all gone under the hill" and ends with a description of "The wave cry, the wind cry, the vast waters / Of the petrel and the porpoise." A community in this country titles a poem that describes "Midwinter spring" as "sempiternal though sodden towards sundown" and ends by declaring "the fire and the rose are one." A poem titled for a house in this country notes that "Time present and time past / Are both perhaps present in time future." Except for (*) The Dry Salvages, each of the Four Quartets are named for locations in this country. This country's legend of the Fisher King is referenced throughout The Waste Land. For 10 points, name this European country, the adopted home of T. S. Eliot.
tossups.answer: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [or Great Britain; accept England, accept Wales or Scotland after the Fisher King clue]
tossups.answer_formatted: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [or Great Britain; accept England, or Wales or Scotland after the Fisher King clue]
acceptable: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

tossups.question: The third part of this novel ends with a description of two tomcats who scrape the remains of dead birds off of engine grilles. After purchasing rope, two characters in this novel visit a convent in an attempt to buy black stockings from a nun. While in prison, a character in this novel writes a letter to Don Cullivan and traps a squirrel he nicknames "Red." The guitar of one character in this novel is stolen while he drinks with Otto and the Cowboy in (*) Acapulco. A parole letter in this novel notes that one character's parents were the rodeo duo Tex John and Florence Buckskin; that character is pursued by Alvin Dewey. In this novel, Kenyon and Nancy are shot after being tied up by Perry Smith and Richard Hickock. For 10 points, name this "nonfiction novel" that describes the murder of the Clutter family in Holcomb, Kansas, by Truman Capote.

This quantity first increases and then decreases as per capita income rises in the Kuznets curve. Globalization and technological changes are not the cause of the rise of this quantity in the US, according to a Joseph Stiglitz book titled for the The Price of this quantity. This quantity increases when r is greater than g, according to the book (*) Capital in the Twenty-First Century by Thomas Piketty. One measure of this phenomenon is calculated by finding the ratio A over A plus B on a Lorenz curve. This phenomenon is measured by the Gini coefficient. Examples of this phenomenon include "the top 20% control 80% of the wealth." For 10 points, name this phenomenon, in which wealth is unevenly distributed across a population.
tossups.answer: economic inequality [accept any form of inequality]

tossups.question: This geographic region's Isua greenstone belt contains one stromatolite contender for the oldest evidence of life on Earth. Records from Camp Century in this geographical region led to the discovery of Dansgaard- Oeschger events, short intense temperature increases. A proposed mining project at Kvanefjeld was the major issue in a recent election in this geographic region. The largest (*) national park in the world protects this landmass's northeast coast. On this landmass, a supply mission to Eismitte claimed the life of Alfred Wegener. This landmass's northernmost point is Cape Morris Jesup. The largest non-Antarctic ice sheet covers this landmass, whose largest city is Nuuk. For 10 points, name this Denmark-controlled largest island in the world, located in the Arctic Ocean.

A work by this artist depicts a young woman playing the title instrument and staring off into the left side of the painting, which was this artist's first work to be accepted in the Paris Salon. In another painting by this painter, a woman wearing a white dress reclines in a patterned chair while reading the newspaper and is titled (*) Reading La Figaro. Degas remarked "there is someone who feels as I do" after viewing this artist's works, and he collaborated on this artist's work Little Girl in a Blue Armchair. One of this artist's works depicts a mother in a striped dress washing her daughter's feet. For 10 points, name this artist, one of the "three great ladies of impressionism," who painted The Child's Bath.

Along with iodine, this compound forms a coordination complex with rhodium in an industrial process developed by BASF. This compound is added to methanol to form acetic acid. This compound reacts with water to form carbon dioxide and hydrogen in the water-gas shift reaction, a side reaction that is suppressed by the Cativa process. This compound is found alongside hydrogen in (*) syngas. This compound is produced in incomplete, but not complete, combustion. Along with smoke, this colorless, odorless, lethal gas is sensed by many detectors. This compound has 230 times the binding affinity to hemoglobin compared to oxygen. For 10 points, name this compound that consists of one atom each of carbon and oxygen.

Remnants of forces from this rebellion went south to fight in flag gangs in the Haw Wars. The leader of this rebellion gained his vision for establishing his regime after going to Thistle Mountain, where he first met many of his future commanders. The rebel side in this rebellion was weakened when their East King tried to stage a revolt in which the North King also died. (*) Charles Gordon was put in charge of the Ever Victorious Army that ended up putting down this rebellion. After this rebellion, the victors carried out reprisals against the Hakka population. The state established from this rebellion proclaimed itself the Heavenly Kingdom in the city of Nanjing. For 10 points, name this rebellion led by Hong Xiuquan, which created a state influenced by Christian theology and fought against the Qing dynasty in the 1850s and 1860s.

By a theorem of Euler, if n is a number named for these shapes, then the number of even partitions of n and odd partitions of n differ by 1. Since the number of sides of these shapes is the second Fermat prime, these shapes are constructible by the Gauss - Wantzel theorem. Numbers named for these shapes are of the form n times the quantity 3 n plus 1, over 2. 12 of these shapes and 20 hexagons form the faces of a (*) truncated icosahedron. The ratio between the length of a diagonal to the length of a side equals the golden ratio in these shapes. A pyramid with one of these shapes as its base has 6 vertices. The exterior angle of a regular one of these shapes is 72 degrees, and the sum of the interior angles of these shapes is 540 degrees. For 10 points, name these polygons with 5 sides.
tossups.answer: pentagon [accept regular pentagon or pentagonal numbers]

tossups.question: The function of this system is supported by SP-B and SP-C, which lower the Krafft temperature. It's not a buffer system, but pH levels in the fluid surrounding the medulla oblongata are used to control this system. A mixture of DPPC and other proteins are used to support one part of this system. This system is supported by the pleural membranes. Mary Ellen Avery showed that RDS, which affects this system, is caused by a lack of (*) surfactant. In humans, this system uses negative pressure to perform one of its main functions. COPD affects this system. The epiglottis prevents food from entering parts of this system. Parts of this system include the diaphragm and bronchioles. For 10 points, name this body system that includes the lungs and helps you breathe.
tossups.answer: respiratory system [or pulmonary system; accept ventilatory system; prompt on cardiopulmonary system; prompt on breathing; prompt on lung surfactant system; prompt on lungs]
tossups.answer_formatted: respiratory system [or pulmonary system; accept ventilatory system; prompt on cardiopulmonary system; prompt on breathing; prompt on lung surfactant system; prompt on lungs]

tossups.question: In the "liberty scene" of a work by this composer, the mezzo-soprano air "Oh Liberty" is followed by the duet "Come, ever smiling liberty." "Let God Arise" is the last of eleven settings of psalms this composer wrote for his patron, the Chandos Anthems. The majority of one work by this composer is sung by roles simply known as the Israelitish Man and Woman. This composer of (*) Acis and Galatea included the chorus "See, The Conqu'ring Hero Comes" in another oratorio. One work by this composer has the strings imitate shepherd bagpipers in the instrumental section Pifa. A work by this composer with libretto by Charles Jennens includes the aria "I Know That My Redeemer Liveth." For 10 points, name this composer of Judas Maccabeus and an oratorio that contains the "Hallelujah" chorus, Messiah.

This person discussed a question and answer session they did with a seven year old girl as part of the speech "To Restore America." This person quoted FDR to end one speech with the line, "You and I have a rendezvous with destiny." In one campaign where he defeated former mayor George Christopher, this person promised to "send the welfare bums back to work." This person said he would "clean up the mess at Berkeley" in a campaign where he defeated Pat Brown to become governor of (*) California. This person supported Barry Goldwater in the 1964 speech "A Time for Choosing." During a speech at the Brandenburg gate, this person asked, "Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall." For 10 points, name this person who defeated Jimmy Carter to become president in 1980.

NetChoice and the CCIA sued to overturn a law passed in this state for violating Section 230; that law would have prevented social media companies from banning political candidates. This state passed Senate Bill 1028, an anti-trans sports ban, on the first day of pride month. The mayor of one city in this state, Charles Burkett, claimed that "we are not resource poor." A 2018 letter from Morabito Consultants pointed out repairs needed for (*) Champlain Towers South, which is located in this state. This state's Agriculture Commissioner Nikki Fried and Rep. Charlie Crist are attempting to unseat a governor who defeated Andrew Gillum in 2018. This state's governor, Ron Desantis, said he was working on a "dual track" with Hurricane Elsa. For 10 points, name this state where a Surfside condo collapsed in Miami-Dade county.

The ambiguous punctuation of this thinker's sentences, like "Of this account which holds forever men prove uncomprehending," was decried by Aristotle in his Rhetoric. A fragment attributed to this thinker states that "the way up and the way down are the same." In Lectures on the History of Philosophy, Hegel claimed that this thinker, not Socrates, should be considered the teacher of Plato. This teacher of Cratylus used the example of the harmony between the (*) bow and the lyre to illustrate their unity of opposites. In On Nature, this thinker, whom Diogenes Laertius called "the weeping philosopher," claimed fire was the sole source of all substance and that the universe was in constant flux. For 10 points, name this Ancient Ionian philosopher, who Plato claimed believed that "you can't step in the same river twice."

Note to players: Description acceptable. In this conflict, one general could not declare war on the Suebi tribe because their leader, Ariovistus, was considered a "king and friend of the people." This conflict started when the leader of a migrating Helvetian tribe died while fleeing from potential death by fire. The losing commander of this conflict was a king of the Arverni tribe. This conflict's namesake region was divided into (*) three equal parts, according to a set of commentaries. In this conflict's last battle, the Romans besieged a city by building a wall around their own army and another wall around Alesia. In that battle in this conflict, Vercingetorix was defeated by Julius Caesar. For 10 points, name this conflict where Rome conquered modern-day France.
tossups.answer: Gallic Wars [accept anything describing wars fought in Gaul by Julius Caesar]
tossups.answer_formatted: Gallic Wars [accept anything describing wars fought in Gaul by Julius Caesar]
acceptable: anything describing wars fought in Gaul by Julius Caesar

tossups.question: The Book of Jubilees states that this character died in "just retribution" when his house collapsed on him. Dispute over the meaning of "et-Yahweh" has led some to claim this man was actually the son of God. A descendant of this man who works as a blacksmith is named for "[this man's] spices" and in one story causes Lamech to kill this man. Apocrypha names this man's sister Arwan as his wife, with whom he fathered (*) Enoch. God promises that anyone who harms this man will be punished seven-fold, and marks this man before exiling him to the land of Nod. This man's brother becomes a shepherd, while this man becomes a farmer. When God asks where that brother is, this man replies, "Am I my brother's keeper?" For 10 points, name this first son of Adam and Eve, who killed his brother Abel.

Many of this author's first published poems cataloged his love affair with Friederike Brion in Sessenheim. Rüdiger Safranski subtitled his biography of this author "Life as a Work of Art." Johann Kestner inspired the character of Albert in one work by this author, who titled his autobiography "Poetry and Truth." When working for Karl August, this author initially intended to write a work on William Tell, but he handed off the theme to his friend Friedrich Schiller. This author detailed his (*) southern travels in the "Roman Elegies" and the "Italian Journey." This author wrote many of his best-known works while serving as a privy councilor in Weimar. For 10 points, name this author whose relationship with Charlotte Buff inspired his The Sorrows of Young Werther.

The concept of this quantity was first introduced by Uhlenbeck and Goudsmit. This quantity is studied in a field that most often uses dilute magnetic semiconductors or Heusler alloys. A namesake type of "-tronics" studies this quantity's application in solid-state devices. The coupling of this quantity to motion contributes to fine structure. A 1921 experiment fired (*) silver atoms through a magnetic field to demonstrate the quantization of this quantity. Two electrons in the same orbital must have different values of this quantity. Electrons can have a value of plus or minus one-half for this quantity. For 10 points, name this quantity that represents the intrinsic angular momentum of a particle.
tossups.answer: spin [accept spintronics or spin-orbit coupling; prompt on angular momentum before mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: spin [accept spintronics or spin-orbit coupling; prompt on angular momentum before mentioned]

tossups.question: When a character in this play is asked about dactyls, he raises his middle finger in response. In this play, one character compares the sound of thunder to the sound his stomach makes after he drinks soup. A character in this play cites "meteorological illiteracy" in his refusal to pay a creditor, before asserting that interest is nonsensical since the amount of water in the world is constant. Near this play's end, one character insists on (*) beating his father since his father spanked him as a child. A character in this play dips the feet of a flea in wax to measure how far it can jump. This play includes a debate between Good Reason and Bad Reason. One character in this play is driven into debt by the horse-racing addiction of his son Pheidippides. For 10 points, name this play in which Xanthias and Strepsiades burn down Sophocles' Thinkery, by Aristophanes.

bonuses.leadin: This work's composer's interest in theosophy led them to give this work the unusual tempo marking "Legendaire"; a contrasting work by its composer was given the marking "Prophetique" instead. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this piano sonata in a single movement, many of whose themes are centered around a minor ninth. This sonata's opening measures contain a variation of its composer's "mystic chord."

One of the reasons why the Black Mass sonata earned its moniker was for its frequent use of these tuplets, sometimes over 5-tuplets. In these tuplets, three notes are played in the time that two would normally take up.

In a dramatic section of the sonata, Scriabin instructs the performer to play in the manner of this genre. Nikolay Rubinstein commissioned Pyotr Tchaikovsky to write a piece in this genre for victims of the Serbo-Turkish war.
answers: "Black Mass" sonata [or Alexander Scriabin's 9th piano sonata, do not accept or prompt on "White Mass"]
march [accept alla marcia, accept Marche Slave or Slavonic March or Serbo-Russian March on Slavonic Folk Themes]
answers_formatted: "Black Mass" sonata [or Alexander Scriabin's 9th piano sonata, do not accept or prompt on "White Mass]
march [accept alla marcia, or Marche Slave or Slavonic March or Serbo-Russian March on Slavonic Folk Themes]
acceptable: Alexander Scriabin's 9th piano sonata, do not accept
Serbo-Russian March on Slavonic Folk Themes

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about fictional languages in video games:
parts: In The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, these creatures communicate in Dovahzul. The primary antagonist Alduin is one of these large, scaly, winged creatures who can breathe fire or frost.

The language Bebebese used to be a voice option for the non-playable characters of this series, although the character K. K. Slider would always sing in this series's default language, where each letter's basic sound is spoken.

Although the characters of this video game speak gibberish, fans used lore tablets scattered around its world to craft their own alphabet. This 2017 platformer has the player fight insects while learning about the Pale King and the Infection in locations like Deepnest.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about potatoes in literature. For 10 points each:
parts: This character invents a parable about two tribes and a field of potatoes to describe his philosophy, humanitism. In a novel whose title is sometimes translated as "Philosopher or Dog?," Rubiao must take care of this character's dog, who shares his name.

The Potato Face Blind Man plays his accordion on a street corner in the village of Liver-and-Onions in this author's Rootabaga Stories. The title city is called "of the Big Shoulders" in this author's poem "Chicago."
In this poem, the author's father is described as "stooping in rhythm through potato drills." This poem repeats the lines, "Between my finger and thumb / the squat pen rests."
answers: Quincas Borba [prompt on partial answer, I guess??? idk]
answers_formatted: Quincas Borba [prompt on partial answer, I guess??? idk]

bonuses.leadin: These ships were built generally to have three masts and both square and lateen sails. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these ships. These large ocean-going ships were developed by Portugal and used to dominate Indian Ocean trade. The term caravel generally refers to a smaller relative of these ships.

These ships were generally smaller than the related carracks, although some, like the São João Baptista, became quite large. A type of this ship named for Manila was used to carry silver across the Pacific Ocean.
Both carracks and galleons were more easily able to sail long distances because of the development of this device, which originated in China. It includes a magnet and a needle.
answers: carracks [accept nau or nao or nefs]

bonuses.leadin: In 1964, Henry Littlefield published an article which alleged that The Wizard of Oz was "a children's story with a symbolic allegory." Answer the following about that allegory, for 10 points each:
parts: Littlefield compared the plot of the novel to a real-life event involving this group. One of this group's demands was for the federal government to print $500 million and put it in a "General County Road Fund System."

According to Littlefield, the Cowardly Lion represented this politician. This politician was the Democratic presidential nominee in 1896 and 1900 and later argued for the prosecution in the Scopes Monkey Trial.

While in Quadling Country, the Cowardly Lion slays a large spider, representing trust-busting in this industry. The Granger Laws regulated prices in this industry, but were eventually struck down by cases like Wabash v. Illinois.
answers: Coxey's Army [or the Commonwealth of Christ]
railroad industry [or the train industry, prompt on transportation industry]
answers_formatted: railroad industry [or the train industry, prompt on transportation industry]
acceptable: train industry, prompt on transportation industry

bonuses.leadin: The optimal rate of these policies can be found on a Laffer curve. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these policies, compulsory financial charges that governments use to raise revenue.
Taxes introduce these costs to society created by market inefficiencies. These inefficiencies are often represented by a triangle bounded on two sides by the supply and demand curves.
Joel Waldfogel controversially claimed that this activity constituted a form of deadweight loss. This activity is also analyzed in his book "Scroogenomics."
answers: deadweight loss [accept excess burden or allocation inefficiency]
Christmas shopping [accept buying gifts or buying presents or giving gifts equivalents]
answers_formatted: Christmas shopping [accept buying gifts or buying presents or giving gifts equivalents]

bonuses.leadin: This quantity's reciprocal equals the plate scale. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity. An object placed at a distance of this quantity from a mirror will produce an image at infinity.
The formula for the plate scale is only valid under this approximation. In this approximation, light rays lie close to the principal axis, which makes the small angle approximation valid.
The paraxial approximation is used in this field of physics. People in this field study how light interacts with mirrors and lenses.

bonuses.leadin: This opera begins with the tenor aria "It is a curious story," sung by the Prologue. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this "chamber opera," with libretto by Myfanwy Piper. During a Latin lesson in the first act of this opera, a child sings the haunting aria "Malo," whose title word could refer to either an apple tree or evil.
This British composer wrote the music for operas like The Turn of the Screw and Peter Grimes. He also wrote a War Requiem.
This tenor, Britten's life partner, debuted the roles of Peter Quint and Peter Grimes. With Galina Vishnevskaya and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, he was one of the intended soloists of the War Requiem.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the proto-Romantic poet Christopher Smart. For 10 points each:
parts: One section of Smart's Jubilate Agno calls one of these animals named Joffrey "the servant of the Living God duly and daily serving him." A Thomas Gray ode on the death of one of these animals concludes with the advice that not "all that glisters" is gold.
The sections of Anne Sexton's Jubilate Agno-inspired poem "O Ye Tongues" are named after these Biblical poems, one of which claims that "The Lord is my shepherd."

In a poem in this form, Smart claims "I shall not make a long oration / In order for my vindication" since "Such stuff is nought but mere tautology." In a passage about "Sporus," another poem in this form asks "Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?"
answers: a cat [accept "Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat Drowned in a Tub of Goldfishes"]
epistle [accept "Epistle to Mrs. Tyler" or "Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot," prompt on letter or other synonyms with "What specific word is in the title of both of these poems?"]
answers_formatted: a cat [accept Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat Drowned in a Tub of Goldfishes]
epistle [accept Epistle to Mrs. Tyler or Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot," prompt on letter or other synonyms with "What specific word is in the title of both of these poems?]
acceptable: Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat Drowned in a Tub of Goldfishes
Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot," prompt on letter
other synonyms with "What specific word is in the title of both of these poems?

bonuses.leadin: The life cycle of these organisms is controlled by the cl and cro proteins. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this organism discovered by Esther Lederberg. This organism's genome consists of two 12-base pair sticky ends.
The lambda phage was discovered in the K12 strain of this gram-negative bacterium. This rod-shaped bacterium can cause food poisoning.
Since the lambda phage is temperate, it can undergo either the lytic cycle or this cycle of reproduction. The virus' genome is incorporated into the host bacteria's genome in this cycle.

bonuses.leadin: Gilles Deleuze claimed that Henri Bergson's philosophy was based on the elevation of this faculty to a "method" in the first chapter of his Bergsonism. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this faculty. In Consciousness Explained, one thinker claims that John Searle's Chinese Room experiment is designed to provoke this faculty rather than to make a carefully-reasoned argument.

Consciousness Explained is by Daniel Dennett, who also wrote a book titled for this thinker's Dangerous Idea. Perceived insufficiencies in this thinker's theory of natural selection led Bergson to theorize the elan vital.

In Consciousness Explained, Dennett rejects this theory of consciousness on the grounds that accepting it would be "giving up." Gilbert Ryle called this theory of Descartes "the dogma of the ghost in the machine."

bonuses.leadin: The leader who founded this philosophy explained that its concept of social justice came from the "Ratu Adil", or Just Leader. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this political philosophy whose five principles included Belief in the Almighty God, just and civilized humanity, and democracy. This philosophy was first articulated on June 1st, 1945, during a speech that pressured Japan to grant independence.
Pancasila was promulgated by this leader who implemented the idea of "guided democracy." This leader helped found the Non-Aligned Movement when he hosted the Bandung conference.
Sukarno was the first president of this Southeast Asian country. This country gained independence from the Netherlands in 1949, and granted independence to East Timor in 2003.

bonuses.leadin: Don't have a cow, man! Answer the following about mythological characters who really really wanted some cows, for 10 points each:
parts: As an infant, Hermes stole a herd of cattle belonging to this other Greek god and traded this god the lyre as payment after being caught. This Greek god had an oracle at Delphi.
This son of Hermes proved the apple doesn't fall far from the tree when he stole the cattle of Sisyphus. This man was also the maternal grandfather of the similarly crafty hero Odysseus.

In order to one-up her husband, Queen Medb ["mev"] launched the Cattle Raid of Cooley against Conchobar ["konhovar"] mac Nessa, who ruled this region of ancient Ireland. The story of Medb's defeat by Cu Chulainn ["ku hulinn"] is recorded in a Cycle named for this region.
answers: Ulster [accept Ulaidh from any extra children]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about techniques in Renaissance art:
parts: Baroque artist Artemisia Gentileschi was known for her use of tenebrism, a style painting that uses an extreme form of this technique. This technique uses heavy contrasts and is named for the Italian terms for "light" and "dark."
By using fine shading and blurring outlines, artists were able to give their paintings a "smoky" appearance through this technique. Leonardo da Vinci used this technique to paint the Mona Lisa.

Netherlandish painter Jan van Eyck often imitated sculptures and frames in his artworks, an example of this technique. Van Eyck used this technique in his Portrait of a Man in a Red Turban, where the frame has been painted to appear as if letters were carved into it.
answers: trompe l'oeil [prompt on deceive the eye and synonyms]

bonuses.leadin: This piece of legislation is intended to address the crisis that Black mothers are the most likely to die from childbirth. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this piece of legislation that was introduced by the Black Maternal Health Caucus in February 2021. This set of bills are intended to provide pre- and post- natal support to Black mothers.
The Momnibus Act was partially introduced by this junior senator from New Jersey. This person was endorsed by Phil Murphy while he was a Democratic candidate for the 2020 election.

The Momnibus act also seeks to improve mental health care for moms in these places. Horrible living conditions and mistreatment led to 1971 riots in two of these places located in Attica, New York and San Quentin, California.
answers: Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act of 2021
acceptable: Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act of 2021
Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act of 2021

bonuses.leadin: The functionality of these algorithms can be explained by the building block hypothesis. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these algorithms that select the best candidate algorithm using a fitness function.

Since genetic algorithms require a fitness function, they are considered this kind of learning. This type of machine learning algorithm uses labeled training data from a set of training examples to make predictions, in contrast to a type of algorithm that prefixes this type's name with "un-."
Machine learning is often used to perform this task of finding the relationship between dependent and independent variables. The "linear" form of this technique finds the line of best fit.
answers: genetic algorithms [or GA; prompt on evolutionary algorithms or EA]

bonuses.leadin: An author from this country wrote of the clerk August Esch in The Anarchist, which they grouped with The Romantic and The Realist in one trilogy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this home country of the author of The Sleepwalkers. The trial of the murderer Moosbrugger is attended by Clarisse and the title Man Without Qualities in a novel from this country by Robert Musil.
This author dedicated an entire chapter of their The Art of the Novel to an examination of Hermann Broch's The Sleepwalkers. They also wrote The Unbearable Lightness of Being.

Elsewhere in The Art of the Novel, Kundera discusses this author's contributions to the European novel. Earlier, Kundera had adapted this author's Jacques the Fatalist into the play Jacques And His Master.
answers: Austria [accept Austria-Hungary, but do NOT accept or prompt on just "Hungary"]
answers_formatted: Austria [accept Austria-Hungary, but do NOT or or prompt on just "Hungary]

bonuses.leadin: Lodovico Castelvetro codified these standards based on his reading of Aristotle. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this set of principles which were widely used by French classicists in their plays. They include setting the play in one place and it taking place over the course of a day.
This French playwright structured many of their plays according to the classical unities, including a play which ends with Theseus adopting Aricia, Phedre. They also wrote Andromaque.
The Phaedra myth was also adapted by this other author in the fourth section of their Heroides. This author also wrote the Metamorphoses.
answers: classical unities [accept three unities or Aristotelian unities]

bonuses.leadin: Carbonyl radicals can undergo fragmentation to produce alkenes and these compounds via beta-cleavage. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these compounds that are produced by the McLafferty rearrangement, where a hydroxyl group is attached to a carbon-carbon double bond.
The McLafferty rearrangement can occur during this technique. This lab technique fragments compounds and sorts them based on their mass-to-charge ratio.

The McLafferty rearrangement only occurs if the compound has a hydrogen in a position denoted by this letter. A quantity denoted by this Greek letter, the adiabatic index, equals 5/3 for monatomic gases.

bonuses.leadin: The first one of these people was legitimized when Maria Nagaya falsely proclaimed him as her son, but lost that legitimacy when he exhumed her real son. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these three people. The first of them challenged the rule of Boris Godunov and became tsar for a year upon his death, while the second and third were nicknamed the Thief of Tushino and Thief of Pskov, respectively.
The False Dmitrys appeared during this period of Russian history, where pretenders to the throne appeared after the end of the Rurik dynasty. This turbulent period was ended by the rise of Michael I.

Sweden attempted to put a duke on the Russian throne during this war, which was fought during the Time of Troubles. This war was ended by the Treaty of Stolbovo, which resulted in large Swedish territorial gains.
